subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The National Education Policy 2020 envisages a system of education in the country that is rooted in Indian ethos and its civilisational accomplishments in all domains of human endeavour and knowledge while at the same time preparing the students to constructively engage with the prospects and challenges of the 21st century. The basis for this aspirational vision has been well laid out by the National Curriculum Framework for School Education (NCF-SE) 2023 across curricular areas at all stages. Having nurtured the students’ inherent abilities touching upon all the five planes of human existence, the pafichakoshas in the Foundational and the Preparatory Stages have paved the way for the progression of their learning further at the Middle Stage. Thus, the Middle Stage acts as a bridge between the Preparatory and the Secondary Stages, spanning three years from Grade 6 to Grade 8.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The NCF-SE 2023, at the Middle Stage, aims to equip students with the skills that are needed to grow, as they advance in their lives. It endeavours to enhance their analytical, descriptive, and narrative capabilities, and to prepare them for the challenges and opportunities that await them. A diverse curriculum, covering nine subjects ranging from three languages — including at least two languages native to India — to Science, Mathematics, Social Sciences, Art Education, Physical Education and Well-being, and Vocational Education promotes their holistic development.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Such a transformative learning culture requires certain essential conditions. One of them is to have appropriate textbooks in different

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: curricular areas as these textbooks will play a central role in mediating between content and pedagogy — a role that will strike a judicious balance between direct instruction and opportunities for exploration and inquiry. Among the other conditions, classroom arrangement and teacher preparation are crucial to establish conceptual connections both within and across curricular areas.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The National Council of Educational Researchand Training, onits part, is committed to providing students with such high-quality textbooks. Various Curricular Area Groups, which have been constituted for this purpose, comprising notable subject-experts, pedagogues, and practising teachers as their members, have made all possible efforts to develop such textbooks. The book for Physical education and well-being, titled Khel Yatra for Grade 7, is meticulously designed to develop motor skills and engage children in the team sports of Badminton, Football and Kabaddi. Age-specific aspects of Yoga are designed to lay the foundation for healthy living. The textbook aligns with the competencies included in the NCF-SE 2023 for this stage.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra emphasises the importance of physical activity and the values and dispositions essential for life. It incorporates cross-cutting themes, such as inclusion, gender equality, and cultural rootedness.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The content and activities are designed to encourage peer group learning, and enrich the educational experience for both students and teachers. While this textbook is valuable, children should also explore interesting local games and play with friends. This book is not only useful for school learning, but is a valuable resource for parents and community.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: However, in addition to this textbook, students at this stage should also be encouraged to explore various other learning resources. Schoollibraries play a crucial role in making such resources available. Besides, the role of parents and teachers will also be invaluable in guiding and encouraging students to do so.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: With this, I express my gratitude to all those who have been involved in the development of this textbook and hope that it will meet the expectations of all stakeholders. At the same time, I also invite suggestions and feedback from all its users for further improvement in the coming years.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The National Curriculum Framework for School Education 2023 (NCF-SE 2023) recognises the criticality of the health and well-being of individuals as a key factor for success in all aspects of life. Considering the focus on holistic well-being, NCF-SE has mandated Physical Education and Well-being as a core curricular area for all stages of school education. To help the teachers and students achieve curricular goals of Physical Education and Well-being, for the first time a textbook has been designed for Grade 7. This book enables students to experience the joy of playing, explore diverse physical activities, practice fitness skills, learn basic sports skills, and immerse in the world of yoga. Sports and physical activities teach important motor skills, socio-emotional awareness and regulation, associated cognitive abilities, as well as the values of self-discipline, hard work, teamwork, and a gracious acceptance of one’s strengths and vulnerabilities.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: To achieve the goals of fitness, sports and holistic well-being, the Grade 7 textbook is designed to have five units.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Foundational Basis of Physical Education and Well-being Physical Motor Fitness

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Badminton

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Football

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Kabaddi

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: i a

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In Unit 1, students explore the connection between physical education (PE) and well-being, emphasizing its impact on personal and social

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: behaviour. Through playing games and engaging in discussions, students will understand the importance of living a healthy lifestyle and how physical activity adds to their overall enjoyment and success. Students will also learn about the safety measures to minimize the risk of injuries and create a healthy environment for the students.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In Unit 2, students learn different fitness components like endurance, strength, flexibility, and balance. The main aim is to understand how each of these components contributes to overall health.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In the Units 3, 4 and 5 focus is on learning new games. Badminton is introduced in Unit 3, Football in Unit 4 and Kabaddiin Unit 5. Through interactive sessions and group exercises, students will discover the excitement of sport and health advantages of physical activity. The emphasis will be on inclusivity, team cohesion, and enjoyment of movement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In the last unit, students immerse in the holistic nature of yoga. They learn about Yama (social discipline) and Niyama (Personal discipline) to inculcate healthy habits for positive behavior. Systematic practice of various yogasanas starting with Sukshma Vyayama (loosening exercises), preparatory breathing practices and step-by-step performance of each asana helps our body to be flexible, strong, balanced and disease free. Various techniques of Pranayama strengthen the lungs, improves functioning of major systems of our body, calm down the mind, improve concentration and help in achieving overall harmony and well-being. To explore the world within us and experience deep sense of peace, tranquility and bliss, students learn different techniques of Dharana (single pointed concentration) and Dhydna (meditation). Learning various yogic practices lays foundation for long and healthy life.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In this book, apart from learning the games and physical activities, students will learn to follow rules, understand the importance of safe practices and fair play, work harmoniously in groups, treat each other with courtesy and respect, as well as, help each other, and

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: experience the joy of playing together. Inculcation of these values and dispositions will partly happen while children are engaged in the physical activities or games and partly, they will be reinforced during circle time after the game. Sufficient time must be given for circle time during the Physical Education and Well-being periods.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Structure and Flow of Classes

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: NCF-SE 2023 has recommended 120 periods for physical education and well-being in Grade 7. Suggestive timetable assumes at least 5 periods of 40 minute each, per week. NCF-SE recommends allocating block period (2 periods together) for physical education and well- being. If it is not possible to allocate two block periods and one single period every week, it is necessary to design single periods with different focus to ensure sufficient time for activities, game and circle time.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Suggestions are given below for two different scenarios of timetable.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Scenario 1 - Five single periods per week.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Scenario 2 - Two block periods for Units 1 to 4 and single period for yoga.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Scenario 1: Three different types of sessions have been visualised to effectively use the limited time in each period and achieve the learning outcomes.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Typei: Maximizes game practice.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Type 2: Maximizes circle time after play to provide sufficient time for discussing cognitive and socio-emotional aspects.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Type 3: Maximizes gamified drills to focus on one specific skill.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: A sample time allocation for a 40-minute duration is given below for all types.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: For a joyful experience, safety of children and effective development of competencies, teachers may follow the instructions given below:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure adequate play area and that there are no obstructions in the play area.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: For group activities, mark the area into smaller blocks to prevent students from running into each other.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: While dividing the teams, make sure that the teams are fair and balanced in terms of bodyweight, height and skills required for the activity.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure that a first-aid kit is available and accessible.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure that students are treated with respect and they feel emotionally and socially safe.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Provide regular encouragement and support to all the students.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure students have access to fair redressal of grievances during the Physical Education period.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Encourage students to be aware of their surroundings while playing. Instruct the students not to aim at the opponent.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Encourage the students to be careful while pushing or pulling the opponent in the activity.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ensure that students do proper warm-up and cool-down. Encourage them to create their own routines.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Provide opportunities to students for interactions before, during and after the class.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Introduce sports skills gradually. Complexity can be increased by playing mini versions of the sport gradually building individual capacities such as observation, reflection, emotional regulation, expanding spatial awareness and peripheral vision, and making quick judgements based on gameplay. Discuss social capacities such as effective communication, collective decision-making, and working together towards a common goal, during circle time and at relevant moments in the sport.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Encourage students to take more responsibility for building a culture of inclusive sports at school. Help them to take an active role in ensuring all students feel safe, motivated, and encouraged to play.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Three sports are offered in this book, teachers has to opt any two as per the feasibility.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Name of various sports introduced in this book are derived from various states, having different dilects. Teachers should encourage the students to learn correct pronunciation of these names.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Warm-up

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Warm-up prepares the body for exercise by increasing blood flow, flexibility, and mobility.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: It includes light activities like jogging, stretching, and dynamic movements.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Warming up helps prevent injuries, enhances strength, and improves coordination.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: It also sharpens focus and prepares both the body and mind for physical activity.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Cool-down

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Cool-down allows the body to relax and recover after exercise by gradually slowing down movements.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Gentle stretching and deep breathing help reduce muscle stiffness, prevent soreness, and promote flexibility.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Warm-up and Cool-down

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Wrist Rotation: Stand or sit with your back straight. Extend your arms in front and form fists. Slowly rotate your wrists in circular motions, first clockwise and then to counter- clockwise. This helps warm-up your

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: wrist joints. 2. Backward Lunges: Stand with your

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: , feet hip-width apart. Step one leg

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: back and lower your body until both knees are bent at 90 degrees. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. Repeat on the other side. This exercise strengthens your legs and glutes.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Toe Raise, Arm Swing: Stand with your

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: feet shoulder-width apart. Raise your

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: left leg and touch your left hand to your

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: left toe while swinging your right arm

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: back. Lower your leg and repeat on

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: the other side. This exercise improves

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: coordination and flexibility. This can

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: be done alternatively also.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Side Lunges: Stand with your feet together. Step one foot out to the side and bend that knee, keeping your other leg straight. Push through your bent leg to return to the starting position. Repeat on the other side. This targets your inner thighs and hips.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Forward and Sideward Lunges with Side Rotation: Perform a forward lunge by stepping one foot forward and lowering your body until both knees are bent at 90 degrees. Twist your torso towards the side of your front leg. Return to the starting position and perform a side lunge with the same side rotation. Repeat on the other side. This combines strength and flexibility.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 6. Joggingin Place: Standinonespotandstart jogging, lifting your knees and swinging your arms as if you were running. This is a great way to get your heart rate up and warm-up your body.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 7. Butt Kicks: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Jog in place, kicking your heels up towards your buttocks. Swing your arms naturally as you jog. This exercise helps improve your cardiovascular fitness and stretches your quadriceps.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Warm-up and Cool-down

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 8. Mountain Climbers: Start in a push-up position with your hands directly under your shoulders. Quickly alternate bringing one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended. Continue switching legs in a running motion. This exercise strengthens your core and increases your heart rate.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: s

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Star Jump: Stand with your feet together and arms by your sides. Jump up, spreading your legs out wide and raising your arms overhead to form a star shape. Land softly with your feet together and repeat. This exercise improves cardiovascular fitness and coordination.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 10. Both Leg Knee Hugs: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Bring both knees towards your chest and wrap your arms around them, hugging them close to your body. Hold for a few breaths and then release. This stretches your lower back and relieves tension.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 11. Child’s Pose: Kneel on the floor and sit back on your heels. Extend your arms forward and lower your chest towards the ground, resting your forehead on the floor. This pose gently stretches your back, hips, and shoulders.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 12. Mountain Pose: Start on your hands and knees. Lift your hips up and back, straightening your legs and arms to form an inverted V-shape with your body. Keep your head between your arms and your heels reaching towards the ground. This pose stretches your hamstrings, calves, and shoulders.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 13. Cat-Camel Stretch: Start on your hands and knees with a flat back. Inhale, arch your back, and lift your head and tailbone towards the ceiling (Camel Pose). Exhale, round your back, and tuck your chin towards your chest (Cat Pose). Repeat, moving smoothly between the two poses. This stretch improves flexibility in your spine.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Warm-up and Cool-down

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 14. Butterfly Stretch: Sit on the floor with your feet

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: together and your knees bent outwards to the sides. Hold your feet with your hands and gently press your knees towards the ground. This stretch targets your inner thighs and hips.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Seated Forward Fold: Sit on the floor with your legs extended straight in front of you. Reach forward with your hands towards your toes, keeping your back as straight as possible. Hold the position for a few seconds. This stretch improves flexibility in your hamstrings and lower back.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Burpees: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Squat down and place your hands on the floor in front of you. Put your feet back into a push-up position, then quickly jump back toward your hands. Stand up and jump into the air with your arms overhead.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This full-body exercise builds strength and endurance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Foundational Basis of Physical Education and Well-being

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This unit highlights the connection between physical activity and_ personal growth, emphasizing fitness, mental resilience, teamwork, and the importance of safety rules. Students will develop motivation, courage, and discipline to take on physical challenges, track their progress, and stay committed to self-improvement. They will also learn to recognize and report bullying, mental health concerns, and _ inappropriate behavior, helping to create a safe and respectful environment.

text: The Ball Progression Game is a fun and engaging activity that helps in improving coordination, teamwork, and ball-handling abilities. It challenges us to work together as we progress along a series of markers while passing the ball back and forth.

text: Warm-up Cool-down Circle Time

text: Feel the muscle

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ghorpadiche Shepoot is a thrilling and enjoyable approach to improve cooperation and physical capabilities. Get ready to run with the ghorpad (also known as goh or goyra) and enjoy the excitement of the chase!

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Warm-up Cool-down Circle Time

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ghorpadiche Working together Shepoot :

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Students should be divided into groups of five to eight students each.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Each team lines up, holding the person in front of them by the waist to form a Ghorpad.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Draw boundaries for the play area with cones or markers.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ One team’s “head” (the person at the front of the line) must be in contact with the other team's "tail" (the student at the back of the line) without letting their own tail getting touched.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Teams start moving together at the teacher's signal, with heads attempting to touch the tails of other teams.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Students need to maintain communication and unity within their team.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Foundational Basis of Physical Education and Well-being

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e When a team’s head successfully touches another team's tail, they score a point.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Students can choose to keep playing without resetting their positions when a point is scored.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e The game will be played for a set duration of time (let’s say 10 minutes).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The team with the most points at the end of the given time frame wins.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Nalugu Rallu Ata is a traditional Indian game, popular in the southern regions, especially in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana. The name means ‘Four Stones Game’. Played by five participants, this game involves strategic movement and teamwork to avoid being caught by the ‘denner’ while collecting stones.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Warm-up i Circle Time |

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Growing mentally strong

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Draw the court as shown in the figure having boxes anda path.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Place four stones right at the centre of the path.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Four students take their positions inside their respective boxes, and four stones are placed at the centre of the path as shown in the figure. The fifth person will be the denner.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The objective of the students is to pick up the stones without being caught by the denner, who cannot enter the boxes but can move in this path.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Students can collaborate or act independently to pick up the stones and distribute them amongst each other, with each student ultimately having one stone.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Once all students have their stones, they ask the denner to choose either ‘Gumpw’ (Group) or ‘Chuttw’ (Circling).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Ifthe denner chooses ‘Gumpu’, all students gather in one selected box with their stones.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e If the denner chooses ‘Chuttu’, each student must make three rounds around the boxes and return to their original position, while avoiding the denner’s touch.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Students are out if they are touched by the denner while moving between boxes. The game continues until one student is out.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Focus on learning new skills and process of playing the game and not on the outcome of the game. This will help you grow mentally strong.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Gidhada Gudkavan is a traditional Indian game that replicates a chase between a hawk (gidhada) and chickens (gudkavan). The game, popular in rural areas, encourages agility, teamwork, and strategy as the hawk tries to tag the chickens, while the mother hen leads the chickens to safety. This fast-paced game has been passed down through generations as an exciting and playful way to stay active.

Students may explore various viewpoints—those of the bully, the target, and the bystanders—through role-play and learn appropriate responses in practical scenarios.

Harassing anyone physically, mentally, or emotionally can lead to serious repercussions for both the victim and the harasser. Through this activity, we will learn how to eliminate this harmful act from our society.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Physical and Motor Fitness

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This unit focuses on improving heart health, muscular strength, and agility through structured exercises and activities. Students will enhance their running, jumping, and movement skills while learning proper techniques for endurance and strength training. They will also explore the importance of warm-up and cool-down routines, ensuring injury prevention and muscle recovery. Through hands-on activities, discussions, and self-reflection, students will experience the role of large muscle groups in movement and develop the ability to sustain physical activity over time. Additionally, they will learn about traditional games from different regions, fostering cultural awareness and diversity in physical education.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Set It Up, Knock It Down is an exciting and quick-paced team game that combines strategy, agility and cooperation. Get ready for a fun-filled experience. ~

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Warm-up Cool-down Circle Time

text: Set It Up, Knock It Down

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Personal Goal

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Mark an area of about 20 by 10 metres.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Place the markers randomly throughout the marked area. The number of markers should be more than the total number of students. An equal number of markers should be facing up or down.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Form two teams of 10 students each. Form two to four team of five to ten students each.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Oneteam will be ‘Markers Up’ and the other will be ‘Markers Down’.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Each team member will also count the number of markers they flipped.

text: ¢ Onthe whistle, the students of the ‘Markers Up’ team will flip

text: Atya-patya is a traditional Bhartiya tag and running game, often referred to as a game of agility and strategy. The playing field is a rectangular court. The objective is for the ‘runners’ to cross as many trenches as possible while the ‘defenders’ try to tag th out. The game emphasises speed, quick decision-makin,

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Defenders stand in each lane and can only move sideways within their designated lanes to tag runners. One of the defenders can start and move in the centre lane.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Ensure safety by encouraging controlled movements and maintaining sportsmanship throughout the game.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The game ends after 4 innings (scoring turns) of 7 minutes each, with each team having two innings to score. The team that scores more points will be declared the winner.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Toe-to-toe: Instead of facing each other, students stand back- to-back about a foot apart in the centre.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Red and Blue: Instead of using calls, throw a piece of cardboard (red on one side and blue on the other) into the air between the teams. If red comes up, the red team chases, and vice versa.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Nouns and Verbs: When the leader calls out any verb, the nouns team chases, and vice versa.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Odd and Even: Throw a large foam rubber dice in the air. If they come up even, the even team chases. If they come up odd, the odd team chases.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 'Serve' is an important skill

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Badminton is a fun and fast-paced sport played with a shuttlecock and a racket. It can be played as singles (one player on each side) or doubles (two players on each side). The objective is to hit the shuttlecock over the net and land it in the opponent’s court to score points. Badminton improves physical fitness, hand-eye coordination, and reflexes. It is an Olympic sport and popular worldwide.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Football

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Football is a popular sport played between two teams, each with 11 players. The goalis to kick the ball into the opponent’s net to score points. Players use their feet, head, and body to control the ball, but only the goalkeeper can use hands. Football improves fitness, teamwork, and coordination. It is the most-watched sport in the world and is played in big tournaments like the FIFA World Cup. It is also known as Soccer.

text: Kicking the Ball with the Inside of the Foot

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Basic moves and strategies

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Kicking with the inside of the foot is a fundamental skill in football that many players use for passing, shooting and controlling the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: You would have done similar activities in the Preparatory Stage (Grades 3 to 5). Let us learn the skill:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. APPROACH ¢ Be in the direction of the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Se +s Place the non-kicking foot pointing towards the target by the side (6 to 8 inches apart) of the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION OF THE SKILL

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The last step will be slightly bigger than the approach run. The kicking leg will get a good swing to connect the ball with the inside of the foot.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Lock your ankle in such a way that the toes are pointing outside, whereby the whole inside of the foot comes in contact with the ball while kicking.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Connect your foot at the centre and behind the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FOLLOW THROUGH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Make sure your kicking foot is in the direction of the target after making contact with the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Lead-up Activity Pair up with your partner and kick the ball toward each other with your instep. Gradually increase the distance to 3 m, then 5 m, and finally 7 m, while also practicing with a moving ball. You can only kick the ball with the inside of the foot. Your partner will score a point if you fail to kick the ball through your instep. Try to increase the speed of the rally to unsettle each other.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Receiving the ball using the inside of the foot is a fundamental skill in football that allows players to control and direct the ball effectively.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: You would have done similar activities in the Preparatory Stage (Grades 3 to 5). Let us learn the skill:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. APPROACH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Face the direction from which the ball is coming and align your body accordingly.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Turn your shoulder and hips towards the direction of the passing to widen your body.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION OF THE TECHNIQUE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Place your receiving foot in front of your standing leg and allow the ball to touch your foot.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: To cushion the ball and slow it down, use the inside of your foot.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FOLLOW THROUGH ¢ At the time of contact with the ball, the receiving foot will be taken back so that the cushioning effect will be there to control the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Lead-up Activity

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Pair with your partner, stand at a distance of 5 m and start kicking the ball towards each other with your inside of the foot. You have to receive the ball through your instep as explained. Make sure that you keep the ball in control while receiving. If the ball deflects while receiving, the shooter will score a point. Try to increase the speed of the rally to unsettle each other.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Passing a rolling ball in football is a fundamental skill that involves delivering the ball to a teammate with precision and control.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: You would have done similar activities in the Preparatory Stage (Grades 3 to 5). Let us learn the skill:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. APPROACH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Make sure your body is positioned correctly in relation to the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e With your toes pointing in the direction of the pass, place your non-kicking foot next to the rolling ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Look up to see where your opponents and teammates are positioned.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ You might need to modify the approach to better control the ball before passing if it is rolling fast.

text: Use your correct foot to strike the ball in order to pass efficiently; for a more controlled pass, use the inside of your foot.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: You must strike the ball at the right time, ideally as it enters your stride.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Depending on how you choose to pass, change the angle of your foot.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Let your foot follow through in the direction of the pass after you've struck the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Make sure your body weight is evenly distributed to maintain your balance both during and after the pass.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Make a swift transition to your next movement after the follow through.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Step Trapping is a fundamental skill in football that involves controlling and stopping the ball with various parts of the body.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. APPROACH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e When you are ready to trap the ball, place your body behind the line of the incoming ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Anticipate the direction, path and bounce of the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Take a low balanced position by bending your knees a little.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION OF TECHNIQUE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Ifthe ball is rolling towards you, simply place your foot directly on top of it to stop it.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Sports — Football

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e If the ball is coming to you on a low bounce, extend your receiving foot in its direction and bring it back right before contact to stop the ball. Make sure that the ball dead drops on impact.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FOLLOW THROUGH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Assoonasthe ballis trapped, get ready to transfer it into space or away from the defender.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Make as many small boxes of 30 inches = 30 inches.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Play this with your partner. One of the partners will stand behind the box and the other partner will roll the ball by hand towards the box from a distance of five metres.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The partner behind the box has to trap the ball within the box. One point will be awarded for one trap.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Each player will set a goal for trapping the ball, for example, five times out of six or three times out of six.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Each will get three chances of rolling a ball and three chances for low bouncing the ball randomly. The player with the maximum points will be the winner.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Dribbling is one of the fundamental skills in football that involves moving the ball with control while running or walking. 1. APPROACH ¢ Bend your knees slightly to lower your centre of gravity to maintain the balance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Keep the ball between your leg and close to the body to protect the football from the defender.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION OF SKILL

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Use both feet’s, inner and outer parts, to control and guide the ball to move in the desired direction.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Apply short and gentle touch to the ball. Adjust the force of the touches on the situations, and the pace so that the ballis in your control.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Keep your head up, to stay aware of the surroundings, especially the location of the opponents and teammates.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Sports — Football

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Dribble the ball while using both feet for unpredictable results.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FOLLOW THROUGH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Maintain the body balance and balance after finishing; continue the dribbling.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Plan for the next action. ¢ Maintain the momentum after execution.

text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The players will take turns for dribbling the ball through the cones in different patterns.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The players who are not dribbling the ball will observe the other players who are dribbling.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The player who will complete the dribble in minimum time will win.

text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: A feint usually involves a sudden shift of body weight, a fake dribble, or a head movement that suggests the player is going in one direction while they actually intend to go another way. The objective is to wrong-foot your opponent in order to make your way with or without the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. APPROACH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ With your knees bent and your body ready to change direction rapidly, maintain a low centre of gravity.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Make it appear as if you are going to shoot, dribble, or pass ina single direction.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION OF THE SKILL

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Use your entire body to make the feint seem realistic by exaggerating the movement of your legs and feet, as though you were going to pass or dribble in that direction.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Push off your planted foot and go in the opposite direction as soon as the opponent responds to your feint.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FOLLOW THROUGH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Once you've managed to trick the defender, speed into

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: the gap produced to move forward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Once you have defeated the defender, consider your alternatives. Your options will vary depending on the situation. Youcanshoot, dribble farther or pass.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Lead-up Activity

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Choose a partner for yourself. While the one player practices feints in front of other, the other player assumes the role of the defender. The attacker practices selling the feint and rapidly changing direction while the defender imitates the attackers moves rather than tackling.

text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. APPROACH ¢ To properly time your contact, align yourself with the ball's path. ¢ Make rapid, little adjustments to your position as the ball gets closer to ensure that you are balanced. ¢ Do it in two steps.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢* To hold the ball down and maintain control, lean a little forward.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION OF TECHNIQUE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ First, receive the ball and take a step back. Then use your instep diagonally to kick the lower half of the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ You should usually aim for the middle or lower portion of the ball while making such a pass.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Depending on the style of pass, use different areas of your foot (instep for longer and driven aerial passes, inside of the foot for shorter and more controlled passes).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Use a smooth, steady leg swing to provide power.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FOLLOW THROUGH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Your kicking leg should continue to move forward naturally after it makes contact with the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Maintain your body's balance while performing the follow-through.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e After making the pass, get ready quickly to go on to your next move.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Stand ten to fifteen feet apart with a partner for the two- player drill.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Pitch a stump in between. Try kicking the football over and above the stump. You will score one point for kicking the ball over the stump. Player with the most points win.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Gradually advance to longer kicks by increasing the distance from the stump; utilise the instep after beginning with short, controlled kicks using the inside of the foot.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: An interception is a defensive action where a player anticipates and intercepts (or takes possession of) the ball intended for an opponent. 1. APPROACH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Keep yourselfready so that you intercept the given pass.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Maintain a low centre of gravity by balancing your weight on your feet and bending your knees.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Continue to look around the field with your head elevated. Wait for the ball to move. 2. EXECUTION OF TECHNIQUE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Judge and wait for the ball's movement towards the target after it has been passed.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Move swiftly into the ball's path and intercept it when it is passed.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Cut across and intercept with an explosive, fast step.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FOLLOW THROUGH ¢ The objective is to keep control of the ball after you've intercepted it. ¢ Make a swift switch from defence to offence after intercepting.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Sports — Football

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Make a circle and let the players stand at the edge of the circle. One or two players will be the defenders who will intercept the ball while others pass the ball through the circle.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The one who successfully intercepts will join the players

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: in the circle and one who made an unsuccessful pass will

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: become a defender.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Person to person marking is a defensive strategy in which one player is tagged to another player of opposition side. The player is supposed to remain close to the opposing side player to refrain the opposing player for receiving a pass.

text: Front Block Tackling

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: eee eee = Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: A front block tackling is a defensive technique in football that aims to dispossess an opponent of the ball without making direct contact with them or committing a foul.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. APPROACH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Get close to the opponent who is controlling the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Keep your body leaning slightly forward, knees bent, and approach swiftly to the opponent.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ To prevent being dribbled past, keep a safe distance. 2. EXECUTION OF TECHNIQUE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Step in to make the tackle as soon as you are within range and the opponent is about to lose control of the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The ball can be blocked or knocked aside by using the inside of your foot. —

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Sports — Football

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ For balance, place your non-tackling foot firmly on the ground as you make the tackle.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Be cautious not to be too aggressive, but use enough force to get the control of the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FOLLOW THROUGH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Return to your starting position as soon as

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: you've completed the tackle.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Get ready to face another player that will be

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: attacking.

text: A goalkeeper is the only player allowed to use their hands and arms to play or control the ball, within the designated area, penalty area.

text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. APPROACH

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Maintain a shoulder-width distance between your feet while bending your knees slightly.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Join your hands in the ‘W’ position. e Always keep your eyes on the ball.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. EXECUTION OF TECHNIQUE *« Using your hands and arms, form a “basket”. Hold your hands close together with your fingers pointing downward and slightly cupped.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ In order to provide a safe landing place for the ball, your elbows should be close to your sides.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Sports — Football

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Allow the ball to enter the basket you’ve made with your hands and arms as it gets closer.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Asyou catch the ball, bend your elbows and bring your hands slightly towards your body to allow your body to absorb the force.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. FoLLOw THROUGH * Once you get the ball in your hands, secure it by bringing it close to your body. ¢ Asa result, the ball won’t returned back or get knocked down by an opponent.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Kabaddi is played between two teams, and the goal is to tag players. Players must touch opponents and return to their side of the court without getting caught. Kabaddi helps build strength, speed, and improves teamwork. It is a popular game in many countries and is also played in the Asian Games.

text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The primary aim of the raiding foot work technique is to prevent raider from defender and return safe after a raid to their own half.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. STANCE

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Keep your feet apart in a parallel or diagonal position; body weight should be evenly distributed on both feet.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

text: Lead-up Activity

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Mark two parallel lines of 30 feet each (9.15 m). Set up two blocks 30 feet apart, opposite each line. Keep two blocks on the other side of the starting line. The player will stand at the starting line opposite the blocks. The player will start running towards the blocks as fast as possible on the signal ‘Ready? Go!’. They will pick up a block and return to place it behind the starting line, then run fast to pick up the second block, then run with it backwards across the line. The player who takes the minimum time to finish the activity will be the ‘winner’.

Every player is given a chest number (same number for both teams). When a number is called out, one player from both sides runs in and tries to take the ball placed in the centre to their side using hands only. The team that succeeds to score a point will be declared the winner.

Just before the player reaches the baulk line, the teacher will randomly call out a shape. The player has to quickly run and toe touch the shape and return to the centre line. Each player will be given equal chances on the basis of time feasibility. The player with the minimum recorded time will be the winner. The remaining students will observe each raid very carefully.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Kick is one of the major offensive skills in Kabaddi used by the raider. The primary aim of the kick technique is to touch a defender with a leg and return back to their own half of the court after a raid.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. APPROACH ¢ Approach depends upon variation of the target and the distance to be covered. 2. STANCE ¢ Stance should be diagonal or parallel. ¢ Maintain stability on rear leg. e Shoulder line towards the mid line. ¢ Upper body to be in crouch position. e Arms flexed and relaxed to balance the body.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. EXECUTION ¢ Kick without flexing the knee joint, keeping in mind distance and position of the target. ¢ Rear leg in pivot position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ After executing the kick, bring the kicking leg forward immediately, to avoid catches by defenders.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Move in bending position towards midline to avoid covers and chain.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. VARIATION The following types of kicks can be used as variation: ¢ Back kick ° Side kick ¢ Roll or Curve kick

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Make two teams stand with their arms extended at the corners behind the bonus line. Both teams will line up in opposite sides of the court; first player will start at the whistle. The objective is that all team members will take turns to go to the opposite court, kick the extended arm and return in minimum time. The team that finishes first will be the winner.

text: DEFENSIVE SKILL

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Some defensive positions are given below:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Corners

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Centre

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ins

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Covers

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The players of the team stand on the extreme right and left corner on the kabaddi court. The responsibility of the corners is to initiate tackles. When the left raider is in action, the right corner is in prime position to initiate any attack and vice versa.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Centre player plays in centre position. The raider of the team mostly stands in the centre position.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The ins are positioned between the corners and the covers. One of the major responsibilities of the ‘in’ is to protect the corner defender from going into the lobby or out of the court. The ins are generally the raiders of the team and also help in defense such as catching the raider.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The defenders positioned between the ins and centre are known as the covers. Generally, the teams position their all-rounders in this position.

text: The primary aim of the defensive ankle hold technique is to catch the attacker in such a way that the raider loses their breath of 30 seconds in the defensive court during a raid.

text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

APPROACH ¢ Before going in for ankle hold, the defender should observe the raider’s foot, and anticipate the next movement of the raider’s footwork. ¢ Bend the upper body towards the raider’s leg completely by bending the leading leg, at the same time bringing both hands towards the raider’s ankle.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. FOLLOW THROUGH e Once the raider is caught, the defender should maintain stability and firm grip, lift the raider up towards the inner shoulder or pull by taking the leading leg back, shifting the body weight backwards or taking small steps towards the end line.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Lead-up Activity

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Draw four different shapes in the court and place four defenders just behind the shape. Every player has a chest number and when the number is called out, the player will run to the baulk line. Just before the player reaches the baulk line, the teacher will randomly call out a shape. The student has to quickly run and toe touch the shape while the defender will try to ankle hold at the time of toe touch. The aim of the player is to return safely while the defender ankle-holds. One point will be awarded for every ankle hold. Each defender will get equal chances.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

text: Lead-up Activity

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Two teams are divided into four students each with varied weights. One player from each team will start at the signal from the teacher, lift their teammate by holding the other players thigh, and then bring the lifted student towards the starting point and again return to bring another player of the team. The drill of both teams will be completed when the last player is lifted to the starting point. The team which will reach first with their last player will win and the same can be repeated by other player.

text: The primary aim of the wrist hold technique is to prevent the raider from escaping or returning to their half of the court after a raid so that the defending team can gain points.

text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. TYPES OF WRIST-HOLD ¢ Holding the wrist from above ¢ Holding the wrist from below

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. APPROACH ¢ Before going in for wrist-hold, the defender should observe, focus and judge the raider’s hand movements.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The defender should be in free and relaxed position without holding the chain.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e The defender palms in a cup shape with the thumb finger apart and the rest of the fingers close together for a firm grip.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e The defender should take the support of the other hand immediately and pull the raider towards end line for proper follow through.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e The raider’s movement should be countered by the defender’s body weight.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: All the player will be asked to hold the trunk of the player in front and form a train. A single player who is in front of the train is the opponent, who will try to touch the last player (compartment) to put him out. All the player will try to guard the last player by moving away from the opponent’s attack without breaking the waist hold. If the player is put out, she will change her position and the game will resume.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: The primary aim of the chain hold technique is to prevent the raider from escaping or returning to their own half of the court after a raid, so that defending team can gain points.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Steps to Learn

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. HOw TO FORM THE CHAIN? ¢ Hold either the wrist or a palm of the other player to form a chain while forming a grip. 2. APPROACH ¢ Form the chain: Chain should be formed with the help of the supporting students.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Cover the path and outer shoulder of the raider and observe the path and attack of the raider very carefully in order to anticipate the movement.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Maintain the grip while approaching the raider.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. STANCE e Stance must be wide.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Shoulder ofthe player involved in chain must be parallel and close to each other.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Khel Yatra

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Grip should be firm in formation of chain.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Position your head towards the line of attack of the raider.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. EXECUTION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Defender involved in chain formation will come close to the raider and cover the raider.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: e Chain should be placed on the abdominal region of the raider.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ The other hand opposite to the chain formation will be used as support to lift the raider from holding the thigh from behind.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Fundamental Skills of Sports - Kabaddi

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. FOLLOW THROUGH Two methods are used in follow-through action: ¢ Lifting the raider at the same spot by taking the wider stance. ¢ Change the direction of the raider by pushing him away from mid line with the chain.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Lead-up Activity

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Form two teams. Line up both the teams facing each other at a distance of six metres approximately. One player from each team will come in the centre and will lock elbows with each other. Both player will sing one to two lines of any folk song while moving in a circle. As the first round ends, both the players will try to pull each other towards their own side. The player that successfully pulls the other player towards their side earns one point. Repeat the process until everyone gets their turn.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Physcial Education 7 - Unit 6.indd 153

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga is an ancient practice designed to harmonise the body and mind. This unit will introduce and guide you through yoga for holistic development, emphasising the practical application of the eight limbs of yoga to achieve both physical health and mental well-being. We will explore how consistent yoga practice can foster self-awareness, discipline and ethical conduct, ultimately empowering students to become more responsible and compassionate individuals.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: About Yoga

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In the Grade 6, we learnt that the word ‘Yoga’ is derived from the Sanskrit root ‘Yuj’, meaning ‘to join’ or ‘to unite’ or 'to integrate.’ It is the union of body, mind and the inner self. Yoga brings balance, harmony and a sense of oneness within us and the world around us.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga helps us to grow in many ways physically, mentally, emotionally and socially. Practising yoga regularly builds a stronger body, acalmer mind and more balanced emotions. This inner harmony helps us become better students, loyal friends, responsible family members, and citizens of the nation. It is necessary to maintain a consistent Yoga practice to handle life's challenges with balance and focus.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Each section in this unit will enhance your understanding and practice of yoga. We will start with an introduction to yoga for holistic Development. Then learn about Yama, Niyama and their applications in our daily lives; Sukshma Vyayama (joint movements), Sithalikarana vyayama (dynamic practices), Surya Namaskara, Asana (postures), relaxation, Mudras, Kriyas, Pranayama (regulation of breath), Pratyahara (mastery over senses), Dharana (concentration,) Dhyana (meditation) and Krida Yoga (Yoga games).

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga Session Structure

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Begin your yoga session with the prayer given on next page. Through this prayer, we honour the bond between students and teachers. Together, they ask for divine guidance, protection and wisdom. They also wish for peace for everyone, everywhere.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Sit comfortably in Sukhdsana with your spine, neck and head straight.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Close your eyes, relax your face and bring your awareness to your breath.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Place your hands in Chin Mudra. Observe your breath for a few moments. Then, take a deep and slow breath. As you exhale, gently chant “Om.”

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Gently place your hands in Namaskara Mudra and chant prayer given in the following page.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Notice how you feel after chanting Om.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ¢ Gently rub your palms together, place them over your closed eyes and then slowly open your eyes to the warmth of your hands.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Chapter 1

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga for Daily Life

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In this chapter, we will explore different ways to integrate yoga into our daily routines. To incorporate yoga into our daily routine, it is necessary to practice ‘Yoga in action’ (Karma Yoga), as taught by Shri Krishna in the Bhagavad Gita. The Bhagavad Gita defines yoga as ‘Yogah Karmasu Kausalam (2.50),’ which means ‘Yoga is skill in action.’ This means doing our tasks ina relaxed and focused way to get the best results.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Think about a Kho-Kho player. They are not just running fast; they are also incredibly calm and focused, even when the game gets intense. That is a lesson for all of us. Whether we are studying, playing a sport, or learning a new skill, it is not just about working hard and stressing out. It is about staying calm, focusing our attention and truly enjoying the process.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Sri Aurobindo highlights that yoga is about overall personality development at the physical, mental, intellectual, emotional and spiritual levels. It is about growing in all areas of life.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Imagine a big tree. For it to be strong and healthy, all its parts—roots, trunk, branches and leaves—must grow together. Similar to this, we must grow in all facts of life to achieve balance and strength.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: How can we grow in different aspects and achieve holistic development?

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga helps us understand the connection between our body, mind, and inner self. Similarly, in Pancha Kosha (44 lS)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ee ee cect Yoga 1 57

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: explained in the Taittiriya Upanishad, talks about the five layers of our existence, much like the layers of an onion. These layers are body, energy, mind, wisdom and bliss. Various Yoga techniques help nurture each of these layers, enhancing our overall well-being.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Let us understand each Kosha and its role in holistic development. The Pancha Kosha framework helps us understand ourselves better. It gives us insight into both our inner and outer worlds, helping us become more self-aware, empathetic and purposeful.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ry ANNAMAYA KOsHA. (Physical Sheath)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PRANAMAYA KOSHA (Energy Sheath)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: MANoMAya KosSHA

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: (Mind Sheath) VIJNANAMAYA KOSHA (Wisdom sheath)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ANANDAMAYA KOSHA (Bliss Sheath)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Annamaya Kosha (Physical Sheath)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This is the outermost layer, which is our physical body—the part we can see, touch and feel. It's made from the food we eat. Playing sports, running, eating healthy food, occasional fasting, living with nature and sleeping well are the ways to make us healthy. Yoga postures help strengthen and balance our physical body. Just like a plant needs water and

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: sunlight to grow, our body needs food, exercise

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: and rest to stay healthy.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Physciall Education

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Pranamaya Kosha (Energy Sheath)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Our bodies have layers, and the one just under our skin is called the Pranamaya Kosha. This layer is powered by ‘Prana,’ our life energy, which we get from breathing. Prana is like invisible rivers inside us, helping our lungs, heart and everything else work together. Breathing connects us to the air and the earth, giving us energy. We can strengthen our Prana with special exercises like Pranayama, Mudra, and Kriyd, helping us feel strong and healthy.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Manomaya Kosha (Mind Sheath)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This layer is about our thoughts, feelings and perceptions. It is where our emotions and desires come from. It includes what we think, how we feel, and how we react to things. Activities like meditation, mantra chanting (japa), listening to music, singing, painting, and Trataka (focusing on a point) help refine this layer. A calm mind helps you solve problems, stay focused on tasks, and handle challenges easily. When you feel happy or sad, it’s your Manomaya Kosha experiencing those emotions.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Vijnanamaya Kosha (Wisdom Sheath)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This layer helps us distinguish between right and wrong, good and bad. It is responsible for decision-making, knowledge, wisdom and understanding. Wisdom from this sheath helps us make the right choices, making us better students, friends, family members and responsible citizens of the nation. It also helps us understand our strengths and weaknesses and discover our life’s purpose. When we learn something new at school or figure out what’s right and wrong, it is our Vijnanamaya Kosha at work. Think of it as the map that helps

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: us navigate life. lees

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Anandamaya Kosha (Bliss Sheath)

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This is the innermost layer and the source of pure joy or bliss. Think about how peaceful and happy you feel when playing with your pet, sitting quietly in nature, pursuing your hobbies, singing and listening to songs, helping others, or contributing to society. That deep sense of contentment f and joy comes from the Anandamaya Kosha. Understanding the five koshas shows us how interconnected we are. Yoga is a tool to nurture and balance all these sheath. By practicing yoga daily, we can improve our focus in school, excel in sports, enjoy our hobbies, and thrive in learning music or art and hence allowing us to reach our full potential in everything we do.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: To achieve all-around development, we need to follow a systematic way of practice. Mahashri Patanjali has created this process known as Ashtanga Yoga.

text: ACTIVITY

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: My Daily Yoga Plan to strengthen the Panchakosha

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Create your own daily yoga plan:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Annamaya Kosha: Write one Yoga posture that you will practice each day. 2. Pranamaya Kosha: Choose a Pranayama that you will do daily.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Manomaya Kosha: List a simple mindfulness activity like japa, chanting of mantra, trataka, etc. that you would like to practice to be calm and focused.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Vijnanamaya Kosha:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: (a) Imagine your self in the future. What kind of person do you want to be, and what skills, values and qualities will help you get there?

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: (b) What small things you do today to start becoming that person?

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Anandamaya Kosha: What gives you a moment of joy—listening to birds, spending time with friends, helping your dear ones, playing with pets, sharing, etc.? Prepare a collage of activities that bring you joy.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Note for the teacher ¢ Explain to students how yoga can nourish and balance the Panchakosha through asanas, pranayama, and meditation.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: YAMA AND NIYAMA

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yama and Niyama are golden rules for a balanced and fulfilling life. Just as we follow rules in school, these guidelines cultivate personal growth and harmonious relationships. Yama refers to moral principles guiding our behaviour with others, making us

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: more kind, honest and responsible human beings.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga 161

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: FIVE YAMAS

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Ahimsa: Being kind to all living beings.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Satya: Always telling the truth and being honest. 3. Asteya: Not to take things that belongs to others. 4. Brahmacharya: Having self-control.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Aparigraha: Not being greedy.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: NIYAMA

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Niyamaare personal habits that help us to take care of ourselves and transform us into better persons. By following Niyamas, we can overcome our limitations.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: FIVE NIYAMAS

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Sauhca: Cleanliness

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Santosha: Being happy and content with what we have. Tapas: Self-discipline and determination to achieve. Swadhyaya: Self-study.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ishwara Pranidhana: recognising the divinity.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In this grade, let us learn about Ishwara Pranidhana. one of the Niyamas, It is about recognising the divinity within our self and surrendering to it.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Ishwara Pranidhana is also about seeing our body as a temple and offering everything we do to the divine within us. Our senses, actions, breath, and even our happiness are all part of this offering. It’s about recognising the sacredness inside and around us and being grateful to it.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Divinity in all

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: We usually think place of worship and prayer rooms are sacred.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: But yoga teaches us that everything is sacred. Pranidhana means seeing the divine in everything — nature, friends, family and even

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: daily work. The story below gives us the message of finding divinity in all.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: A Journey of Oneness

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Guru Nanak was a great spiritual teacher who believed that

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: God is everywhere. One day, he was on a pilgrimage to a holy

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: city. Tired from the journey, he laid down to rest. A devotee : saw Guru Nanak and was concerned.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: “Your feet are pointing towards our holy place of worship,” he said. “It’s disrespectful.” Guru Nanak, politely asked the devotee to place his feet where there is no holy place.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: But no matter which way the devotee moved Nanak’s feet, he still saw the place of worship in front of them. Then devotee recognized divinity of Guru Nanak and apologised to him.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: This story shows us that for Guru Nanak, every place was divine. He believed that God is present in all directions, places and in all creations.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ACTIVITY

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Different communities have different beliefs and traditions. Give some examples of how people perform rituals and explain the reasons behind their actions. For example, harvest festivals are celebrated to thank the Earth for food. It shows that Earth is alive and deserves our respect.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Note for the teacher

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Encourage the students to take a walk in nature. Let them notice the pretty things around them and understand how everything works together. For “ al at example a tree with birds and small animals on it.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Students can keep a gratitude journal. Let them list five or more things they are grateful for everyday.

text: Yoga 163

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Chapter 2

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga Sadhana

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Namaste Young Yogis! Let us delve deeper into the fascinating world of Yoga!

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In the previous chapter, we learnt about Yama and Niyama. Now, let us learn and practice Asana (postures), Pranayama (regulation of breath), Pratyahara (mastery over senses), Dharana (focused concentration), and Dhyana (meditation). We will also learn and practice breathing practices, Sukshsma Vyayama, Sithalikarana Vyayama, Sirya Namaskara, and Krida yoga.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: It is important to learn these practices under the guidance of the teacher at school and self-practice at home every day to get better. Regular practice (Sadhana) makes us stronger, focused, flexible and calm. By practicing this, we can improve our focus and stay calm during studies, sports and doing important tasks. So, let us take a deep breath and stretch ourselves and start this amazing journey.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Yoga is about feeling good! Always listen to your body while

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: practicing and follow the general guidelines for Yoga.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: GENERAL GUIDELINES FOR PRACTICING YOGA

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Breathe normally: Do not force deep breaths or hold your breath. Breathe normally through your nose.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Be aware: Pay attention to your breath, muscle stretch and relaxation while practicing.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Stay focused: Watch your teacher and follow instructions. Focus on your own posture.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: —— ae

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Rest if unwell: If you feel unwell (cold, headache, stomach ache, etc.), rest and ask your teacher for guidance.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: ASANA GUIDELINES:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Warm-up first: Begin with warm-up exercises like Saksma — Vyayama and Sithilikarana Vyayama to prepare your body and reduce the risk of injury.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Practice on an empty stomach: The best time is in the morning on an empty stomach. If practicing later, wait 2-3 hours after eating.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Breathing: Breathe naturally through your nose with slow, deep breaths.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 4. Wear comfortable clothing: Choose loose, comfortable clothing and practice without shoes and socks.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 5. Avoid strain and over-stretching: Listen to your body. If a posture feels painful, gently come out of it. Never push yourself too far.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 6. Focus on alignment: Proper alignment is key. Pay attention to your posture to get the most benefit.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 7. Stay calm and focused: Avoid talking during practice. Focus on each posture and how your body feels.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 8. Cool-down with relaxation: After Asanas, relax in Shavasana or another relaxation posture to unwind.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 9. Be consistent: Regular practice is better than occasional practice. Try to practice a little each day.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: PRANAYAMA GUIDELINES:

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 1. Breathe naturally: Always breathe through your nose. Pranayama should be natural and easy. If you feel dizzy, stop and inform the teacher.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 2. Sit comfortably: Sit with your back straight and hands resting on your knees. or igh

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: 3. Start slowly: Begin with a few minutes and build up slowly. Check with the teacher: If you have respiratory issues like asthma or if you’re feeling unwell, check with the teacher before practicing Pranayama.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Remember, Yoga is about gradual progress. Keep practicing and

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: see how it transforms you.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: SUKSHMA VYAYAMA

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Sukshma Vyayama is a series of gentle exercises designed to loosen the joints, release tension and improve flexibility and strength. The term ‘Sukshma Vyayama’ comes from Sanskrit, where ‘Sukshma’ means ‘subtle or micro’, and ‘Vyayama’ means ‘exercise or movement’. These simple exercises are accessible to everyone with limited mobility, and beginners new to Yoga. They can be performed while sitting or standing.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: Each movement should be sychronised with the breath, enhancing the flow of Prana (vital energy) throughout the body. This helps eliminate energy blockages in the joints and improves coordination, self-awareness and a sense of well-being. This set of practices promotes deep relaxation and prepares the body and mind for practicing Yogdsanas.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
text: In this grade, let's learn Sukshma Vyayama for the fingers, wrists, elbows, shoulders and neck.

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION

subject: PHYSICAL_EDUCATION
